items.name: Clare Museum
items.desc: Clare Museum. Row House, now Temple Gate Hotel, is where Daniel O’Connell planned his historic election campaign. In 1853 it was renovated for the Convent of Mercy. The Convent was extended to include a gable-fronted Gothic Revival Chapel, with stained glass window by Meyer of Munich and hammer beam roof. The property was divided into two sections: the wing on the left now houses the Tourist Information and Clare Museum.

items.name: O'Connel Monument
items.desc: O’Connell Monument (1865-1867). The tall Doric column marks the actual site of the chamber where Daniel O’Connell’s election was announced.

items.name: O'Connel Square
items.desc: O’Connell Square. A huge majority in 1828 elected Daniel O’Connell to the British Parliament in the courthouse that stood on this site. His election forced Britain to lift its bar on Catholic MPs and led to the Act of Catholic Emancipation that was granted on the 13 April 1829.

items.name: The Old Courthouse
items.desc: The Old Courthouse Site (1735-1745). The gable facing you, to the left, contains part of the courthouse’s ashlar façade. If you stand in the square and line up this buttress and Arthur’s Row, you will be able to judge the area covered by the courthouse.

items.name: Cruise House
items.desc: Cruises (1658). Cruise house was built in 1658 by the Protestant merchant John Cruce. Under a 1683 bye-law, any individual residing in the Cruise house could evade arrest for debt by claiming sanctuary as this house was located within the old friary precinct.

items.name: Ennis Friary
items.desc: The O’Brien Kings of Thomond founded the Franciscan Friary in the 13th century. The Abbey remained in almost continuous use as a church from the 1280s until 1871. The friary was officially suppressed in 1543 but the friars remained under the protection of the O’Briens until 1569. The well-preserved ruins consist of a nave, chancel, belfry and an arcaded cloister. The sacristy is an impressive structure with ribbed, barrel-vaulted ceiling.

items.name: The Cloister
items.desc: The Cloister (c14th century) incorporates an area that is part of the adjoining 13th century Ennis Friary. Part of the original medieval cobble floor of the friary survives and there is an integration of 18th and 19th century features within the restoration of the building.

items.name: The 1916 Memorial Stone
items.desc: The 1916 Memorial Stone (1966) was designed by Seán Rowsome to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of the Easter Rising.

items.name: The Club Bridge
items.desc: The Club Bridge (1835) replaces an earlier three arch structure that was built in the 1690s and demolished in 1835.

items.name: The County Club, Bull Hall
items.desc: The County Club, Bull Hall (1740s). The landlords of Clare used this residential club from about 1801 until the early 1900s, “provding a meeting and eating place … for Protestants with business in the town”. The complex consists of a series of two and three storey buildings of differing ages.

items.name: The Courthouse
items.desc: The Courthouse was erected in 1850. It is a quadrangular building with a limestone ashlar façade consisting of an ionic portico and two flanking wings. The Chronicle reported that this, “magnificent and stupendous edifice” would be “a great ornament to Ennis”. The Crimean Cannon, outside the Courthouse, was captured by Irish troops fighting in the imperial British Army, during the Crimean War (1854 – 1856).

items.name: The Presbyterian Church
items.desc: De Valera (The County) Library is located in the single cell Gothic Revival former Presbyterian Church built in 1853. It opened for worship in 1857 and closed in the early 1960s.

items.name: The County Library
items.desc: The County Library was initially located at 7 Bindon Street when it first opened to the public in 1932. The conversion of the Presbyterian Church in the County Library won it a European architectural award in 1975.

items.name: The Manse
items.desc: The Manse (1857) was built for Rev. Thomas Warren, a Presbyterian missionary from the United States. This is where the Local Studies Centre (1988) is based. As a reference library and research centre it holds a comprehensive collection of resource material on the geneological, history, archaeology and topography of Ennis and County Clare.

items.name: Ennis Grammar School
items.desc: Ennis Grammer School (1775-1891) now Maoin Cheoil an Chláir, opened in the former Erasmus Smith Academy in 1993. The building is a detached multiple-bay three-storey building with a steeply pitched roof with four large rendered chimney stacks.

items.name: Bindon Street
items.desc: Bindon Street is named after the Bindon’s of Clooney. Francis Bindon (1695-1765) was the architect who pioneered Palladian-style architecture in Ireland. Bindon Steet was established in Georgain times and almost completed by a tontine company during the reign of Queen Victoria. Bindon Street was built in two phases. The first houses built here were numbers 3, 4, 5 and 6. Captain Charles Hervy Bagot wrote that he had designed, “four handsome houses of 24 feet front equal to London or Dublin second-rate houses”. These four houses were completed by 1833. The houses are terraced Georgian-style townhouses.

items.name: St. Columba's Church
items.desc: St Columba’s Church was built between 1868 and 1871 under the patronage of the Church of Ireland. The asymmetrical-plan French-Gothic style church is built on a site donated by the Bindon Blood family. The interior of the church is fairly plain and rusticated providing a foil for the works of Catherine Amelia O’Brien and Rose Brigid Ganley

items.name: Harriet Smithson
items.desc: Harriet Smithson was the composer, Hector Berlioz, first wife and was born here, 6 High Street. Harriet’s debut was at the Cron St Theatre in Dublin in 1815 and by 1818 she was appearing at the Drury Lane in London. In 1827 she took the role of leading lady with the English Shakespeare Company, at the Odeon Theatre in Paris. On Harriet Smithson’s death Liszt sent Berlioz his condolences: “She inspired you, you loved her and sang your love for her, her mission was fulfilled”.

items.name: Jacobean Chimney Stack
items.desc: As you look northwards you will see the 19th century shop front of McParland’s (locally known as Ms Irene Clune’s house) that is reputed to be the oldest inhabited building in Ennis. Tradition maintains that it was the residence of the Catholic Bishop of Killaloe during the Penal Period. The rare triple-diamond Jacobean stone chimney stack dates the building to 1580-1650. Archaeological excavation has revealed a number of oak timber beams that have been dated to the late 16th century placing this as the earliest surviving example of a timber-framed house in Ireland.

items.name: James Barrett
items.desc: As you look northwards you will see the 19th century shop front of McParland’s (locally known as Ms Irene Clune’s house) that is reputed to be the oldest inhabited building in Ennis. Tradition maintains that it was the residence of the Catholic Bishop of Killaloe during the Penal Period. The rare triple-diamond Jacobean stone chimney stack dates the building to 1580-1650. Archaeological excavation has revealed a number of oak timber beams that have been dated to the late 16th century placing this as the earliest surviving example of a timber-framed house in Ireland.

items.name: Marcus Keane
items.desc: Marcus Keane (1815-1883) was in born in Chapel Lane. He was an Irish speaking local landholder and land agent who was known as The Exterminator General of Clare due to his career in the eviction of smallholders.

items.name: Gaurranakilla
items.desc: Gaurranakilla, the grove of the church, was the town’s earliest ecclesiastical site. The actual church was demolished in the 1830s, possibly after the graveyard was closed.

items.name: Cathedral of Sts.Peter and Paul
items.desc: By the early years of the 19th century, the Catholic chapel in Chapel Lane was too small and in 1821 a parochial meeting decided to build a new chapel. Francis Gore, a Protestant, donated the site in 1828. Dominic Madden designed the limestone ashlar Cathedral of Sts. Peter and Paul. Work began in 1831, and though incomplete, the Cathedral opened for worship in 1842. Work on the base tower started before the famine, but the spires and porches were not built until 1871. The original façade has been partially obscured by the later added porches and spires, but the doorways can still be seen from the inside. The parish church became a cathedral church in 1889 when, the Bishop of Killaloe, Thomas McRedmond took up residence in Ennis. As it was not specially built for this purpose it was called a pro-cathedral until 1990 when Bishop Harty presided over the dedication of the cathedral and altar.

items.name: Former Town Hall
items.desc: The Old Ground Hotel dates from the early 1700s and was built as a private dwelling that was leased by Charles Mahon for “three lives”. When Charles Jane MacNamara converted the Georgian residence into a hotel in 1895. Sinn Fein used the hotel as their campaign headquarters from 1917 onwards. This was during the famous election of that year that launched Eamon de Valera’s political career. The Old Ground Hotel’s association with Sinn Fein lead to the building being ransacked and the furniture burnt by the Black and Tans and the Royal Irish Constabulary in 1920. Harry Mills, manager of Bannatynes’ Mills, entertained the crowd with a rendition of God Save the Queen before the piano was put on the flames also.

items.name: Former Town Gaol
items.desc: The Town Hall, now a part of the Old Ground Hotel, occupies the site of the old jail. The jail built in 1813, and extended several times, had yards and a heptagon-shaped cell-block arrangement radiating out from a central administration building. Prisoners were largely either debtors, convicts sentenced by the assizes, many awaiting transportation to Australia, or short-stay prisoners held for petty offences. Among the later number the town’s prostitutes figured often, as they deliberately committed crimes in order to obtain access to medical treatment as the services of the county infirmary was confined to the respectable. In former times there was a bridge leading from an upper window of the town hall across the street to an exercise ground for the prisoners. Beneath the carpeted floors, excavations revealed dungeons under the building, the chains attached to the walls – are now in Clare Museum.

items.name: Jostle Stones
items.desc: Jostle Stones on the corner of Cooke’s Lane off O’Connell Street prevented damage to building walls from passing horse-drawn carriages. As is evident even today, the medieval layout of Ennis with its narrow streets and laneways gave little leeway for manoeuving with the horse.

items.name: Springfield School
items.desc: Springfield School was established in Springfield House (1740s) in 1843 for secondary level education of Catholic boys. In 1846 the Diocese of Killaloe lent its patronage and henceforth it functioned as both a diocesan seminary and boarding school with a two-fold purpose of educating

items.name: Springfield School
items.desc: Springfield School was established in Springfield House (1740s) in 1843 for secondary level education of Catholic boys. In 1846 the Diocese of Killaloe lent its patronage and henceforth it functioned as both a diocesan seminary and boarding school with a two-fold purpose of educating

items.name: Maid of Erin
items.desc: Maid of Erin is an allegorical figure representing Ireland. Her statue was erected in 1881 to commemorate the Fenian Manchester Martyrs, who were wrongly convicted and hanged in public in 1867. After the execution, Frederick Engels wrote to Karl Marx predicting that, “yesterday morning … the final act of separation between England and Ireland” had been achieved.

items.name: Westborne House
items.desc: Westbourne House (1856) is marked by the ornate cast iron gates and cut limestone piers. The Bishop’s Palace is a large Italianate style house. It is the residence of the Catholic bishops of Killaloe.

items.name: Victoria Bridge
items.desc: The elegant shallow limestone arched Victoria Bridge was erected in the 1840’s to commemorate Queen Victoria (1837-1901).

items.name: Garden of Rememberence
items.desc: The Garden of Remembrance is an idyllic spot that commemorates all children who have died and for parents and families who have lost a child or children. At the centre is a limestone sculpture, by Jose Croft, of a child releasing a butterfly.

items.name: Cut Stone Weir and Sluice Gates
items.desc: The Cut Stone Weir with salmon pass and double sluice gates date from the 1850s and replaced earlier ones on the same site. The island cum park, directly across the channel from you, once formed part of the northern riverbank.

items.name: The Mill Office
items.desc: The Mill Office is a single story house with Doric doorcase and timber fan-light that dates to about 1840.

items.name: Cut Stone Mill Race
items.desc: Cut Stone Mill Race and waterwheel, built in the 1830s, form the surviving parts of Ennis Corn Mill. The cast iron sluice gate is directly upstream with the cut-stone faced mill pond leading to the mill race. Together they comprise part of the water management system of the former mill buildings.

items.name: The Mill Corn Stores
items.desc: The extensive Mill Corn Stores and The Russell Corn Stores (1830s) controlled the bulk of the trade of grain from Ennis. During the famine of 1842, the corn stores on Mill Road were the focal point of assembly of the poor that escalated to riot in June 1842.

items.name: The Mill Corn Stores
items.desc: The extensive Mill Corn Stores and The Russell Corn Stores (1830s) controlled the bulk of the trade of grain from Ennis. During the famine of 1842, the corn stores on Mill Road were the focal point of assembly of the poor that escalated to riot in June 1842.

items.name: The Russell Corn Stores
items.desc: The Russell Corn stores (1830s) are built of rough-cut limestone ashlar with brick heads to the windows and is a total of 9 bays and 6 storeys.

items.name: The O'Gorman Mansion
items.desc: The O'Gorman Mansion (need text)

items.name: St. Mary's Franciscan Church
items.desc: The Gothic styled St. Mary’s Franciscian Church (1885), the modern friary, is of cruciform plan. Distinct Irish features include the Irish crosses on the gables. The Church is dedicated to the Immaculate Conception.

items.name: The Poor Clares Convent
items.desc: The Poor Clares are the Second Order of the Franciscans and were founded in Ennis in 1958. The order is a traditional enclosed contemplative monastic community dedicated to a life of prayer, and has been described as, “ a power house of prayer in the Diocese of Killaloe and the town of Ennis”. The Poor Clares of Ennis provide a visible sign of prayer for the community from the Convent Chapel.

items.name: Stamer Park House
items.desc: Stamer Park House (1700s) was one of a number of gentlemen’s residences in Ennis. It was the home of the Stamer family in the 18th century. George Stamer was a protestant Englishman who settled in County Clare after the Cromwellian settlement.

items.name: Cusack Park
items.desc: Cusack Park (1936) commemorates Michael Cusack who regarded athletics and the games of hurling and football to be intrinsic features of traditional Irish culture. Whilst not overtly aligned to political stance, the GAA was resolutely nationalistic, excluding members of the police or armed forces and people who played ‘imported games’.

items.name: Glór & The Causeway Link
items.desc: Cusack Park (1936) commemorates Michael Cusack who regarded athletics and the games of hurling and football to be intrinsic features of traditional Irish culture. Whilst not overtly aligned to political stance, the GAA was resolutely nationalistic, excluding members of the police or armed forces and people who played ‘imported games’.

items.name: The Clonroad Fairs
items.desc: The Clonroad Fairs (c 16th Century) predate English law. They were held at a strategic point at the centre of the county’s road network and on one of the principal fording points of the River Fergus. The two fairs of Clonroad are listed among the principal fairs of Ireland in 1741 and were advertised in all the Dublin directories until the end of the 18th century.

items.name: Site of O'Brien's Castle
items.desc: Clonrod House is located on the site of the O’Brien stronghold, O’Brien’s Castle (1242-1730), though no visible evidence of the castle survives. Dineley’s sketh of 1680 illustrates a tower house with an adjoining mansion and outbuildings.

items.name: Knox's Bridge
items.desc: Knox’s Bridge (1965) commemorates Alexander Knox who brought Clonroad House in 1904.

items.name: Clonroad Quay
items.desc: Examination of Dineley’s sketch of O’Brien’s Castle shows Clonroad Bridge, Weir and Pool of Ennis. The stone formation under the current bridge (dated 1968) indicates a natural crossing point. Clonroad Quay (1700s), west to the bridge, fell into disuse in the 19th century.

items.name: Clare County Council
items.desc: Ennis become the capital of the newly-established County of Clare by 1569 when the term County Clare first appeared on official papers. Clare County Council administrative centre was opened in 2008.

items.name: CBS School
items.desc: In 1826 Dr McMahon, Bishop of Killaloe, asked Brother Ignatius Rice, founder of the Irish Christain Brothers, to open a school in Ennis to provide education for the poor boys of the town. Initially they used an old corn store off Cornmarket Street providing education for c 400 students. The current school dates from their return to Ennis in 1858, following a 14 year absence from Ennis.

items.name: CBS Monastery
items.desc: The Christian Brothers were invited by the Catholic cergy to Ennis as a response to the actions of prosletysing religious societies. The Christian Brothers’ Monastery was opened in 1869.

items.name: Newtown Stacpoole House
items.desc: The Christian Brothers’ School moved into the Newtown Stacpoole House (18th Century) in 1833. The new school availed of building grants from the National Board of Education.

items.name: The Fair Green
items.desc: The Fair Green covers an area of nine Irish acres and was walled in by 1870 on the instructions of Lord Leconfield’s agent. Lord Leconfield purchased the Fair Green for the holding of fairs in the 1850s. The rights to the fairs were then purchased by Ennis Urban Council. The Council however were unable to obtain a government loan for the purchase and had to raise the money on the open market. The Houses of Parliament (UK) defended its refusal to grant a loan by highlighting the Council’s poor financial accountability. Fairs were held there until the 1960s when Ennis Mart took over.

items.name: Tim Smythe Memorial Park
items.desc: The Fair Green was renamed the Tim Smythe Memorial Park in recognition of the Ennis International Cross Country Champion, Tom Smythe.

items.name: Ennis Union Workhouse
items.desc: Ennis Union Workhouse (1842) occupied a six acre site and was designed to accommodate 800 inmates. During the famine years police were needed to protect its doors in order to keep the numerous applicants out. The workhouse became St Joseph’s Hospital (1970).

items.name: Ennis Union Workhouse
items.desc: Ennis Union Workhouse (1842) occupied a six acre site and was designed to accommodate 800 inmates. During the famine years police were needed to protect its doors in order to keep the numerous applicants out. The workhouse became St Joseph’s Hospital (1970).

items.name: Lifford Cross
items.desc: According to the Irish cartographer, Thomas Moland, Ennis town had not expanded into Lifford by 1703. Lifford Cross has been known as “Kelly’s Korner” since the 1950s.

items.name: Steele’s Terrace
items.desc: Steele’s Terrace is a terrace of houses built as artisans’ dwellings in 1912.

items.name: The Courthouse
items.desc: The Courthouse - text missing!!!

items.name: De Valera Monument
items.desc: De Valera Monument (1979) is a bronze statue of the former President of Ireland and County Clare representative, Eamon de Valera. It was sculpted by Jim Connolly.

items.name: The People's Park
items.desc: The People’s Park (1870) is overlooked by the Courthouse and is where the de Valera monument is located.

items.name: Steele’s Rock
items.desc: Steele’s Rock is an unusual monument that marks the location where Tom Steele (1788-1848) sat and dreamed of romance and ‘cherished an ardent sentiment of attraction’ for Miss Crowe.

items.name: Site of County Gaol
items.desc: The Site of the County Gaol. The last gaol built in town, was considered a masterpiece, it had yards and a heptagon-shaped cell-block arrangement radiating out from a central administration building.

items.name: Paddy Con's New Hall Ballroom
items.desc: The six-bay two-storey former dance hall, Paddy Con’s New Hall Ballroom, was built in 1950. The surviving interior galleried dance hall is an intact example of a 1950 Ballroom of Romance.

items.name: Station Road Terrace
items.desc: Bohernalicky, the flagged road, was the original name of Station Road. It became known as Jail Road and Station Road in the 1800s.

items.name: Railway Station
items.desc: Ennis Railway Station dates from 1859 when Limerick and Ennis were connected by rail. Merely to get the first train moving took a labyrinthine of proposals, counterproposals, false starts, politicking, and bankruptcy.

items.name: Quin Road Railway Bridge (1865)
items.desc: Quin Road Railway Bridge (1865)

items.name: St Anne’s Terrace
items.desc: St Anne’s Terrace dates from the 1930s.

items.name: Ard na Gréine
items.desc: The name Ard na Gréine can be translated into English as, Ard meaning “height or peak” and na gréine meaning “of the sun”.

items.name: Patrick Hogan
items.desc: Patrick Hogan (1887-1969) served as Cean Cómhairle of Dail Éireann from 1951-1967. As a young man he joined the Gaelic League and the Irish Volunteers that resulted in his deportation to England as a result of his activities.

items.name: St. Michael’s Villas Grotto (1954)
items.desc: St. Michael’s Villas Grotto (1954)- need text

items.name: Connolly's Villas
items.desc: Connolly's Villas

items.name: St Flannan’s Terrace
items.desc: The row of houses known as St Flannan’s Terrace or as the Black Cottages were erected as labourers’ dwellings in 1912.

items.name: St Flannan’s College
items.desc: The neo-Gothic St Flannan’s College evolved from Springfield School. Due to the bankruptcy of the builder, alternations to the plans necessitated that some of the finishing touches have remained incomplete. Of note are the plain uncarved label stops around the Gothic windows and the Clock Tower bereft of its clock.

items.name: St Patrick’s Terrace dates from 1890.
items.desc: St Patrick’s Terrace dates from 1890.

items.name: Avodale House
items.desc: Avondale House (c1825) is an impressive private house that has been fashioned out of part of the old military barracks. Two bastions with pistol loops survive in the front wall of the barracks..

items.name: Former Guard House
items.desc: Former Guard House (c1860) - need text

items.name: Military Barracks Wall
items.desc: Former Guard House (c1860) - need text

items.name: Breandán Mac Lua
items.desc: Breandán Mac Lua (1935-2009) was the co-founder and former editor of the London based newspaper, The Irish Post. He often remarked on the foolhardiness of publishing a newspaper with the word ‘Irish’ emblazoned in bold green ink on its masthead at the height of the IRA bombing campaigns in England.

items.name: Linnane's Terrace
items.desc: Linnane’s Terrace, like the nearby Ahern Terrace, dates from 1902.

items.name: Former Boy's National School
items.desc: The first registered pupil at the Former Boys National School (1897) was a Patrick McCallan of Doora who was registered in 6th class in 1898 and struck off the roll on the 30th April 1898. The school roll records World War II child evacuees from England and conversely, children in the 1940s and 1950s who were struck off the roll as their families emigrated.

items.name: Ahern's Terrace
items.desc: Ahern’s Terrace dates from 1902.
